problems.title: Plinko
problems.inputSpecHtml: The only line contains the text "Game x", where x is an integer between 1 and 10 (inclusive) — the number of the current round of the game.
problems.outputSpecHtml: Output a single integer representing the number of the column you want to drop into.

problems.title: Would It Be Unrated?
problems.statementHtml:
It's a disaster. During the last April fools round, Codeforces crashed and consequentially, the round was unrated. No one knows what happened to some of the poor authors afterwards.

After careful investigation, the Codeforces team has found out the reason behind this catastrophe. Apparently, authors added too many tests as they forgot the pretests were equal to system tests.

We don't want to repeat this unfortunate incident and cause this round to be unrated as well. That's why we ask you for your help. Could you please help us check how many tests this problem has?
problems.inputSpecHtml: The question — how many tests does the problem have?
problems.noteHtml: I'll forgive you for lying this time, but you better tell me the right answer next time I ask!

samples.input: Hello! Can you please tell me how many tests does this problem have?

problems.title: Where Am I?
problems.outputSpecHtml: Output two real numbers −90≤a≤90−90≤a≤90 and −180≤b≤180−180≤b≤180, with up to 6 digits after the decimal point.

problems.title: Pair Count
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a prime number p, n integers a1,a2,…,an, and an integer k.

Find the number of pairs of indexes (i,j) (1≤i<j≤n) for which (ai⊕aj)(a2i⊕a2j)≡kmodp.

Here ⊕ denotes the bitwise XOR operation.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains integers n,p,k (2≤n≤3⋅105, 2≤p≤109, 0≤k≤p−1). p is guaranteed to be prime.

The second line contains n integers a1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤p−1). It is guaranteed that all elements are different.
problems.outputSpecHtml: Output a single integer — answer to the problem.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example:

(0⊕1)(02⊕12)=1≡1mod3.

(0⊕2)(02⊕22)=8≡2mod3.

(1⊕2)(12⊕22)=15≡0mod3.

So only 1 pair satisfies the condition.

In the second example, there are 3 such pairs: (1,5), (1,6), (3,6).

problems.title: Definitely a Geometry Problem
problems.statementHtml:
Megumin is a wizard who can cast powerful magic spells that affect large areas. She is obsessed with the extremely devastating Explosion spell that can destroy everything around its target.

There are currently nn slimes in the wild. Each slime's location can be described in 2D Cartesian coordinates. Megumin wishes to kill at least kk slimes so she can earn more experience points to level up her Explosion. To do that, she can choose any circle on the plane and cast an Explosion spell which kills every slime inside or on the border of the circle.

However, the Explosion magic requires a large amount of mana to cast, and Megumin can only use it once per day. The amount of mana used is equal to the area inside the circle she chooses. What is the minimum amount of mana she needs to spend to kill kk slimes with a single Explosion?
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains two integers nn and kk (1≤k≤n≤1051≤k≤n≤105) — the number of slimes and how many slimes Megumin needs to defeat.

Each of the next nn lines contains two integers xx and yy (−109≤x,y≤109−109≤x,y≤109), denoting the coordinates (x,y)(x,y) of a slime's location. It is guaranteed that all locations are distinct and that no three slimes lie on the same circle.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
Print one real number — the answer.

Your answer is considered correct if its absolute or relative error does not exceed 10−610−6. Formally, let your answer be aa, and the jury's answer be bb. Your answer is accepted if and only if |a−b|max(1,|b|)≤10−6|a−b|max(1,|b|)≤10−6.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, Megumin can hit the slime with a circle centered at (0,0)(0,0) with radius 00.

In the second example, Megumin can hit the first and last slimes with a circle centered at (1,0)(1,0) with radius 11.

problems.title: Blurry Vision
problems.statementHtml:
Please direct your vision to line number xx.

Now, read the word you see on that line.

If you struggle, I might have to prescribe eyeglasses.
problems.inputSpecHtml: The only line contains one integer xx (1≤x≤111≤x≤11) — the line number.
problems.outputSpecHtml: Output the word on line number xx.
problems.noteHtml: If you fail to read the first line, even glasses won't save you.

problems.title: Mysterious Script
problems.statementHtml:
An extraterrestrial species has visited the authors of April Fools Day Contest 2025 while they were preparing problems. They call themselves the "Balikons" and expressed interest in chatting with humans. Although they can make sounds that are similar to human speech, they seem to prefer communicating by writing using a variety of media.

Fortunately, there is a linguistics expert in the author team. With some effort, they were eventually able to fully understand the Balikon language. The following is a table of some example phrases they translated.

After some conversations, the Balikons learned about a popular human activity called competitive programming and were excited to try. In fact, they just created their first problem. Please check it out!

∗∗a dish in traditional Balikon cuisine, similar to meatballs

††currency unit
problems.inputSpecHtml: The input contains two integers aa and bb (1≤a,b≤1091≤a,b≤109).
problems.outputSpecHtml: Print the sum a+ba+b.

tutorial.contentHtml:
2095A — Piecing It Together

Credits: flamestorm

Solution

If you complete the puzzle, you will get a line of Python code reading print("puzzling"). To solve the problem, you just need to print puzzling.
